div1.head: S.R. McC. to M. Paul Ayres Rockwell April 4th. [1917]
div1.p:
This is the day I have always written to Jim. Alas there is no longer any need, but I must not give pay to the thought that he is lost to me. That fear has hung over me for several months, a dark premonition of his tragic leave
of this world, and prostrated me. I feel now that he is nearer in spirit, than when fighting so far away. His chivalrous love for France, his brave fight for human rights, are inspiring and lift my faint spirit to meet his in pride and love. I had a letter from him since his death, in which he said he never wished more to live. He was engaged
to be married was he not, to Mlle. Helene Du Bouchet? He had written much to me of her great kindness to him and of his fondness for her. If they were betrothed would you mind asking her to send me her picture? If she would be so good it would be a sweet favor bestowed upon his mother, who longs to hold those in memory who played a great part in his life.
I enclose a most beautiful tribute to him from President Alderman, one for you and one for Mlle. Du Bouchet, which I’m sure will give great pleasure to both. I heard that it is his intention to ask permission of the French government to bring my son’s remains to be buried in the grounds of the University so the memorial will be a monument
a tall shaft I believe. Jim gave me long ago the address where his perso- nal belongings are stored. It is Hotel Beauvou, 24 Rue de Miromesneil [sic], Paris. When these can be sent safely, or any recognition of his devoted services from the French Army, please send to me to 65 Bellevue Place, Chicago Ill. Because of your
loyal and devoted friendship for Jim I subscribe myself

closer.seg:
Jim’s middle name is Rogers, my maiden name, a Virginia name — and it would please me to have his name given in full. He and Kiffin, your valiant
brother are united in eternal fellowship and at peace. Let us believe that with a firm faith.
I am at present in Seabreeze Fla. but leave for Chicago April 21st. Hoping to hear from you as soon as most convenient
Again yours S.R. McC.
